glossentry.glosssee: A definition of a type of issue, which is essentially a collection of attributes. Common issue types are "Bug" or "Enhancement".
An instance of an issue type inside a module. An issue is something that a user has entered into the system.
An attribute is an item of data to be stored about an issue. Attributes represent things like names, dates, status', descriptions, etc.
Modules are where issues are created. Modules let you group issues together (e.g. per-project, or per-customer).

sect1.title: What is Scarab?
sect1.para: Scarab is a customisable issue tracking system. It allows you to create issue types that suite your needs, then collect and track data on those issue types.

It is web based and written in Java. It stores issue information in a database, MySQL being the primary platform, but it is also rumoured to work on Oracle, PostgreSQL and DB2. It runs as a J2EE web application (WAR), and by default, comes bundled with the Tomcat servlet container. This, along with a MySQL database is all you need to get up and running.

sect2.title: How Scarab Differs from other issue tracking systems
sect2.para: Scarab is extremely customisable. It contains no hard-coded workflow (e.g. Bugs move from Open to Closed) and no hard-coded issue type definitions. You have complete freedom to define your issues the way you want them. The downside of this is a bit more start-up effort, but you get something that more closely fits your needs.

Most other issue-trackers (Bugzilla, Issuezilla, SourgeForge, Gnats) contain issue-processing logic as part of the application. This means you're often stuck in the workflow defined by that system. Scarab does not limit you in this way and gives you a much bigger gun to blow your foot off with.

chapter.title: Basic Concepts
chapter.para: In this section, we'll examine the basic concepts that drive Scarab so that when you see the user interface, you'll understand what is being represented on screen.

sect1.title: The Anatomy of an Issue
sect1.para: Scarab is a system for storing issues. Because everyone has their own idea about what kind of issue data they should be capturing, Scarab lets you define your own structure.

sect2.title: Issue Types
sect2.para: An issue type is a description of the structure of a set of issues. An issue type might be a Bug, a Defect, a Work Order, a Help Request, etc. It is up to you to define what your issue types are. Issue types themselves are not issues, they simply describe what information can be captured for that type.

There are two kinds of issue types. Global and module. Global issue types themselves only act as a template for creating issue-types on a per-module basis (for a description of modules, see lower down). Module issue-types are what define the information that is captured for each issue-type in each module.

sect2.title: Attributes
sect2.para: Attributes are the pieces of information that you bundle together in your issue type definitions. An attribute is an atomic piece of information, like "name" or "description" or "Operating System".

Attributes are created globally in Scarab. Where possible, it's a good idea to re-use attributes between issue-types. This will allow you, should you want to, to produce reports for issues across different modules that share common attributes.

sect2.title: Issues
sect2.para: An issue is an "instance" of an issue type. An issue is what you enter data for. Issues are given a unique identifier. In addition to the attributes you define in the issue type definition, an issue also has the following information associated with it:

listitem.para: You can attach (multiple) files to issues. This is useful for adding extra information related to an issue alongside it (i.e. a logfile that was taken when a bug was found)

Arbitary comments can be added to issues. This is where general commentary about the issue is stored (i.e. discussion about the issue). Comments are appended as they are added, as opposed to issue attributes, which contain only a single value.

You can create associations between an issue and users in the system. The "name" of the association is configured by you as part of the issue type, and will usually look something like "assigned to", or "owned by" or "interested in". Again, these associations are only informational, and don't actually infer any different functionality in Scarab based on their value or name (i.e. it's up to you to interpret what the information means).

sect2.title: Issue modification audit trail
sect2.para: All changes to everything on an issue is tracked in the issues audit trail. For changes to issue attributes, you almost always (comments are the exceptions) have to supply a reason for your change. All changes are logged, along with the reason for each change.

chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: In this section, we'll outline the basic installation process. Because Scarab is written as a J2EE Web Application, this means that you can deploy it in a few different ways. Scarab comes bundled with a copy of Apache Tomcat, a servlet container, that you can use to run Scarab out-of-the-box. Take a look at the later section "Alternative ways of running" for some clues on how to run Scarab in a not out-of-the-box way.

chapter.title: Using Scarab
chapter.para: This section will outline how you use Scarab in a day to day way. We'll cover all the common things you do, as well as some of the not-so-common ones.

In general, the majority of the tasks that you will perform inside Scarab will be related to the creation and update of issues. However, there are a few other things you can do and sometimes need to do before other portions of the system will do anything useful.

sect2.title: Creating a new Issue
sect2.para: 1. Select the appropriate module
2. Choose the issue type you want to create
3. Fill out the details for the issue
4. If present, identify duplicates
5. Complete!

sect2.title: Cross-module Queries
sect2.para: If you've defined the same issue-type (or even remotely similar issue types that share attributes) in multiple modules, you can create queries that span many modules. This is useful for finding out things across many projects (i.e. show me all open issues in modules X, Y and Z).

sect2.title: Pre-defined queries
sect2.para: There are a couple of pre-defined queries. The "My Issues" query will show you all issues that have you assigned in some way as a "personnel attribute".

sect2.title: Saving queries
sect2.para: Queries can be saved, making it easy to create queries that do things like "show me all bugs in the "open" state", or "show me all bugs that were opened this week".

sect3.title: Personal vs. Module wide
sect3.para: Personal queries are only visible to you, module-wide queries are visible to all people in that module and require approval to create (although, you may have that permission yourself).
